name: 文學理論導讀
description:
Objectives 
This course introduces to students various modes of modern theory including Marxism, psychoanalysis, postmodernism and postcolonialism. Besides a comprehensive historical survey of these theories, students will be required to read, discuss, and critique some representative theoretical texts in detail and to develop accurate, critical understanding of such essential concepts as reification, ideological interpellation, the unconscious, the ego-superego-id structure, drive, Panopticon, simulacrum, to name only a few. Some cinematic and literary texts will be analyzed in light of these theoretical concepts.

Psychoanalysis and Horror

Cory Han-yu Huang

Objectives

This course places its focus on the psychoanalytic approach to horror. The course starts with a general introduction to some key themes, movements and issues of horror fiction. Then, psychoanalytic concepts such as the unconscious, repression, the uncanny, castration, anxiety, abjection, melancholia, paranoia, and so on, will be introduced through close reading and discussion of original theoretical texts with a view to applying them to representative horror works like _Frankenstein_, _Dracula_, Poe’s “Ligeia,” “William Wilson” and Friedkin’s _The Exorcist_.

Requirements

Attendance and participation 30%, oral report 20%, journals OR term paper (5 to 8 pages) 50%
